So, I am pretty sure my IQ is upper average. Somewhere between 115 and 125. For reference I can tell I'm not a genius, there are times when I can tell I'm miles ahead of other people. IQ, intelligence, basically just boils down to how fast you can put something together. Provided someone with 95 IQ spends enough time with the same set of information as someone who has 125 IQ, they will likely reach the same conclusion. That's why they call dumb people slow. They tend to arrive at the same conclusions just not as quickly.

IQ does not matter. I think it's a decent measure of intelligence but since I'm like a junky or something idk I just like the buzz of learning. So when I'm reading something that I'm interested in, or taking notes about that thing, I get a buzz.

Being genuinely interested and engaged with something is more important than IQ any day of the week. When I was 16-17 I met a girl at a concert, got her number and talked on the phone/computer with her for a few weeks, she lived in another town about 4 hours away so visited her a few times. I could tell she liked me but I was too scared to make a move because I had really low self esteem and never had a girlfriend before.

One time I brought my best friend with me and was trying to muster the courage to make the move, figured having a friend with me would help.

This time however I could tell the vibe had changed, she didn't seem very interested in me anymore, anyway night came and we were all sleeping in her room, 3 separate beds.

Before I fall asleep I hear "is he asleep?" "yeah" and my best friend climbs into her bed and starts fucking her.

I was so shocked I just lay there and experienced a range of emotions. Betrayal, humiliation and the surprise at myself that I was so much of a pussy that I just laid there and pretended to sleep, trying to cry silently when the girl I loved was getting fucked a meter away from me.

I learned on the busride home that they had been talking for a while without telling me. I confronted my "friend" but he just said "what? You didnt make a move so I figured you weren't interested".

I felt very cold and empty after that and my low self esteem was now down to zero.
The memory of it comes back to me occasionally, even nearly 20 years later. I think it has subconsciously affected me because I struggle to trust people and I've had a very hard time connecting with women after this.

It's currently 2 AM and I've been mulling it over for 2 hours now, unable to sleep. this happens occasionally, maybe once every 2-3 months. This is the first time however that I'm telling anyone about it so I guess I'll ask: How do I move past this?

That might not work... but didn't for me.
I used to work as a sort of engineering consultant, and had to regularly talk to with lots of people. Not just other engineers, but managers, finance people, and military officers as well. I used to give presentations to dozens of people at a time. It wasn't right away, but I pretty quickly got very confident in all of those settings, talking about whatever technical shit it was at the time. I could get the whole room on my side pretty easily...
But then, after or in between meetings, when everyone is just sort of hanging out chatting with each other... I'd just shut down. I couldn't handle that kind of interaction. If we were traveling and went out to restaurants or bars in the evening, my colleagues would go off and meet people or hit on chicks, while I would sit there by myself. It's pathetic and embarrassing, but just who I am, and I don't think it's fixable.

The point I was trying to make is that there's a lot of advice out there saying that if you improve your life: get a good job, earn money, be successful... then that will somehow automatically translate over to your ability to get women. I'd bet that the correlation between being successful and getting women is small to non-existent. If you want to get better at getting women, focus on that. Don't put effort elsewhere and expect it to carry over.

I also never went to college or learned to battle whatever natural kind of ADD I had in high school.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hi anon, I'm in a somewhat similar situation, except for abusing meth. I think one of the main issues is that you have become out of practice socializing (maybe, not sure how often you try) -- I face the same issue of losing my train of thought,reacting unexpectedly, and also having a poor memory. Have you ever thought of going to recovery support type groups, even if you don't need the support from drug addiction, it can be a good way to practice socializing with others in a relatively low-judgement environment, who understand where you're coming from and the issues you're dealing with.

I don't think the weed is actually worsening the structure of your brain, but probably isn't helping with the poor memory and lack of focus. I'm a bit of a nootropics fiend, so I'd recommend trying those to help you out in the meantime -- particularly, dopa mocuna (helps with energy and motivation levels, which I know firsthand is an issue with ADD/ADHD) and possibly and rhodiola root (which helps to improve memory). I've had good experiences (have tried a lot of supplements out there in hopes of helping with my depression and brain fog) with both of these with not really any diminishing effectiveness.

And as for daily mental exercises or habits to try, I'd say meditation (if you can), or maybe those brain-training apps you can get on your phone. Even doing things like sodoku or chess can help to give your brain a workout of sorts. If you have the attention span, reading can help a lot -- I've found since I switched from just merely consuming/watching things and doing more active things like reading, my memory has improved. Even just a few pages a day can make a difference. Probably blanking on other suggestions but hope this was somewhat helpful!

>>27917268
I honestly had to learn to dance for a wedding reception. There is a terrific video on You Tube on how to do just that. He had great advice:

1) don't think about learning any "moves" or specific dances. stay in your lane.

2) focus on the person you are dancing with. just face them, move your feet to the beat like you're in marching band but without lifting your knees like a weirdo. you can go one foot slide in or out, or one foot slide back to front a little.

3) keep your hand down. Right around waist level or a little lower, but comfortable. Forget you have arms and hands and it's just like walking.

These are the basics. Start with slower music. Any girl you ever meet at a clubs is going to be way more interested in herself than anything else. This is always the case. If you make eye contact and can walk and talk at the same time without falling over, you will be fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27919052
One thing I'll say is if you get cut off, finish your sentence anyway. You don't have to get all the way to the point, but do finish the sentence even as they're talking.

Allowing yourself to be stopped mid sentence like that does two things.
1) it allows others to not notice you were interrupted. If there are suddenly two voices speaking, it's clear you weren't done talking.
2) it subliminally tells people your point wasn't important, as even you were willing to let it go when presented with someones stronger point of view.

You don't have to get louder - maintain the same tone and volume but just say your sentence to completion and your confidence will increase and people will slowly start to take more notice of you.

Another trick - plan your pauses for mid sentence for impact, rather than pausing in between sentences which can make people think you've finished speaking.

As someone who is average as fuck but is dating a man who is basically what you want:

>be conventionally feminine appearance wise
Long hair, conservative amount of make up (a bb cream, blush and eyeliner/mascara), wear dresses. You want to wear dresses a couple inches above the knee, no lower or higher.

>be a good homemaker
Cooking, cleaning, growing your own food, making your own clothes will all attract the right kind of man.

>be feminine personality wise
Which means being bubbly, pleasant to be around, optimistic. Smiling is your best weapon here.
Treat everyone with kindness, be caring, thoughtful, considerate and selfless.
Remember to be adaptable and non confrontational. Don't be passive aggressive, but also don't have a temper. Don't accept mistreatment and set clear boundaries when necessary.
Don't complain.
Show loyalty and have set morals that you stick to.

>Be sexually selective, modest, reserved
Don't sleep around. Don't show off your body on social media. Don't get dating apps. Make your man wait a little bit (a month or two).

>use empathy, kindness and care to get a good man
Men you want to marry are receptive to women who are motherly, kind and would make good wives. Show the man you like how good of a wife and mother you can be.
Be appreciative of his efforts, make him feel noticed and valued every time you can.
Anticipate his needs. Men love this kind of stuff. It can be as small as bringing him a snack when he's hungry or asking him if he wants a cup of coffee because he seems tired.

>be fun to be around
Learn as much as you can. Make sure you ask your man questions, let them expand on their interest, be willing to listen and learn. Take part in their interests if they want you to. Take a joke, be willing to make one.

>be financially responsible
Career and money don't matter as much, but don't be stupid financially.

>>27905345
Meditation/yoga unironically helps. Or prayer/calisthenics if you need trad style. Basically find a habit/exercise that focuses your mind with your body. Yoga and mindful meditation work for me and millions of suburbanites and city heathens far from nature and gods. Pick up hiking and breathing exercises for all I care.

Also other suggestions like reading help. Drawing helps me. Truth is its all a way of getting meandering imagination to work at something. Even if the something is pointless its at least pointlessly involved with something physically outside the mind. This challenges the mind more than your own daydreaming. Wears it out. Doesnt mean its a cure all.

Think of the imaginative daydream part of your mind as a young labrador dog in a small apartment. Fucker wants to do shit. But the owner is in a restrictive neighborhood and dog has to keep good and quiet. Weirdly the dog has an anxious habit of pacing often, endlessly bored and wasting the owners rest time making small whines for attention. But the simple fix isnt just walk the dog but exercise it. Get the lab running and introducing it to new smells new dog butts new plants and run it more. Wear the dog out and the dog wont have as much energy to restlessly pace the small apartment.

So figure out how to wear your brain out. Cant draw and too lazy to learn? Write a journal. Write a historical fiction novel with no goal of publishing them put it on ao3 one day. Read weird books over watching weird shows because reading at least requires your imagination to do some lifting.

>>27906563
Yeah I have had this problem since I was young. Wasted my teens and 20s doing this. Trust me the cure is doing stuff.

Nowadays I let myself daydream cause at least its distracts me from overthinking real world bullshit out of my control. I guess thats all daydreaming ever is but at least I am now conscious of it enough to control it.

The doing creative stuff or reading and mental stimulating hobbies (example tabletop games might be something you get into that leads to friends at least) help to let out the restless imagination. But the more mental meditative habits build your ability to redirect from restless daydreaming to more restful creative hobbies so do try both. Also exercise and lifting. Lifting helped me in that it gave me guilt free time to daydream but it also distracted me from daydreaming as I got more focused on why the fuck isnt my form right? If you can daydream well enough while doing some exercise thats a great way to get it out too. Biking and hiking are my favorite ways. Swimming in the summer is great to do.

Sometimes you cant force stop the daydreaming but you can force yourself to do some menial exercise or do the dishes while daydreaming. Makes the tasks easier. Almost makes them fun and makes you less guilty about time wasted daydreaming.

Dont waste too much daydreaming time inert is all.

There is nothing mystical about your addiction. If you keep clicking on the tiktok app on your phone, change its location. If you still keep on doing it, save all your fav videos to your phone and delete your account. Only keep your messaging apps on your computer so that you can chat to people in the evening when you're home. Delete unwanted social media from your phone delete the accounts etc.

If you're on the computer and can't stop yourself lock yourself out of accounts. Change the password to something like askdajlksdakjlsdkjsla that you won't remember and save it somewhere that takes a while to access.

The point is to not be afraid of simple solutions. Do not await this magical bout of willpower that will make you do things "the proper way". People 50 years ago did not have to reckon with IG or social media they were just able to live lives without it, so why would you make a huge stink of this? Social media is not the natural state.

After this you actually need to replace social media with something worthwhile. Now this will require actual willpower from you but that's something that youwill just have to find within yourself other people can't tell you.

>>27917946
I don't have data to back any of this up but these are rough estimates based on my own experience plus rough averages of a lot of reported data that I found.
>what's a normal salary in your city
Average individual income is in the neighborhood of $50-55k/year, average household income is around $85-90k.
>what's the living cost
For an individual, ~$25-30k/year. For a family of four it's about double that. Personally I live alone and my total spending is a bit higher, mostly because my rent is higher than average. So my annual cost of living is more like $40k and I make about $65k.
>are men still the only breadwinners, or can i assume that most households receive money from both parents?
In the majority of cases both parents will have an income, though on average men do make more money even when both parents have an income.
>could you believe in the 63% figure? if not, what's your guess?
I could believe 63% are living paycheck to paycheck because when cost of living is 75% or more of your income, you don't have a lot of room for spending on things like hobbies or to do things like save for retirement or build alternate income streams. It can be done, obviously, but it takes a lot of discipline.
Obviously 63% do not make $100k or more. That kind of income is not very common.

The way i'm dealing with this sort of feeling is by deviding myself into some sort of role i am in.

At work i try to be as focused on working as i can and hold private life conversations to required minimum.

Doesn't mean i lie(i do rarley) i just listen and decide wheter it's required of me to share my thoughts with the person i'm speaking with, outright shut the conversation down by getting the person trying to chit chat me focus on their work or saying i'm busy, and sometimes i just nod and don't care if i already see the value of conversation doesn't really go anywhere and is thoughtless spewing words that will go into wrong direction if i share my honest thoughts.

During family time i just focus on asking people what was their day like or about overall events they're dealing with just to show i care and i will listen to them if something's wrong.

With friends i am just the way i am and that's why i love meeting up with them althou i rarley critique them if i see they're doing something potentialy harmful to themselfs. I am willing to just tell it to them bluntly if they cross the line and so they are when i do(which i am very grateful for)

Do not simplify my advice to "tell them what they want to hear" since for me it's more of meintaing a balance beetwen being honest and maintaining the role i need to play. Video games are a huge part of my life. I grew up as a shut-in in a hometown my family moved to, away from their family. I had no family support, even when my dad got cancer -- my community around me decided to just crack cancer jokes, even just days after the funeral.

I played games as an escapism. Online multiplayer. The people on there are still friends a decade later. Some I've had lunch with IRL. One helped me move across the country and I have a solid career because of him.

But in that time, I always felt it was the lack of anime/games that kept me from liking the average normie IRL. To me, the idea of something like Twitch.tv was this amazing pretense. A whole website dedicated to people showing off games they like too and communicating with them? Surely no such thing would flourish -- there aren't enough people.
But we have it today. And when you look at it, even with people in the same realm of interests -- it's all scantily clad porn and shit tier memes and takes.

As I grew older, I realized it wasn't the interests that helped me make connections to people and that I only hated people who liked sports because they're normies -- I just fucking hate the average person.

It’s totally normal to not have the same interests as other people. Part of learning to get along with people and have fun with them is to simply recognize that you aren’t interested in what they’re currently talking about, but that you can still listen to them so that they feel appreciated and cared about. Then they will probably do the same thing for you whenever you talk about what they aren’t interested in. Once you build that trust, you can explore things you both like and more easily have a pleasant/fun relaxed time together. You don’t even need to have ANY similar interests, honestly. You just need to be comfy with eachother and be able to communicate without feeling tense. If you can do that, you can be friends with anyone you want.

Just develop a passing interest in some normie things so that you have more to talk about, Anon. Remember always that while it’s good to have standards, you are also doing other people and yourself a disservice by judging everyone else in advance and shutting yourself off to those relationships. We are social creatures, after all, and talking to normies occasionally doesn’t mean you have to become one.

Consider involving yourself in a few borderline hobbies. Guns, cars and history are common ones that both autists and normies share. You can also build a friendship pretty easily by humoring someone and allowing them to teach you some of the surface level stuff surrounding their hobby. People don’t get to feel useful very often outside of work and it makes them feel good to share things they know with someone new. You can learn a new hobby and make friends at the same time.

1. turn off your notifications for new matches and only leave them on for new messages if you must. This helped me to put it down and stop endlessly, addictively swiping. It also gives a chance for the bots to match you, then get deleted, without wasting your time or demoralizing you.
2. As a general rule of them any girl that matches with you and immediately messages you is no genuine
3. Pay to play, whether it's plus gold or platinum, your card may be kept at the bottom of a girl's "stack" unless you pay to have it moved to the top. This might help you understand why you aren't getting a lot of matches, you need to understand how many no and yes swipes a girl has to go through before she even sees your profile.
4. Keep in mind something like 70% of users are not even actively trying to date, so there really is a only a small percentage of real, local people that are open to meeting you. Don't get frustrated

I found 1 really solid girl this way after months of wasted time. Get a few bad dates under your belt for the experience so that hopefully when you meet that 1 solid girl, the date goes well and you can continue seeing her. Worth the 70 bucks I spent imo

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>27917780
Creative people live working lives. So what they do is work. They have a creative process and that process is their job. Ideas are worthless unless executed. If you have a lot of ideas written down, then take one of those ideas, or a handful of them, and spend 1 hour per day organizing them and executing them. It's an additional hour of work outside of your job.

Creative stuff isn't actually fun most of the time, it is actually work. I blow off steam playing the guitar but I never write songs because the songwriting process isn't fun for me.

So I would suggest if you want to make something, you have to treat it a bit like a second job. Your job doesn't actually end with your money job. Your second job starts after you get home. If you simply apply yourself you will see results. You just won't be relaxed with them.

To put it another way, creativity has more to do with a disciplined process than it does having unique ideas. That's the fun part, the challenging part is then putting it together.

Making money with creativity is possible, and actually a lot of talentless hacks get away with it because of a university degree and most importantly a DEDICATION TO PROCESS over anything else. The art actually sucks, but the process produces a saluable product. Let that sink in.
